body: Hi maxd, apologies for the late response. I actually missed out on this issue until going through the issue list. I believe this query can be caused by querying empty segments. Can you check what the sizes of your segments are?

Druid will accept timestamps perfectly fine down to the nanosecond (e.g. 2013-04-02T23:12:09.000000001/2013-04-02T23:23:09.123456436 will parse fine) but internally timestamps are truncated to the millisecond.

In this case the query is malformed because the interval end is prior to the interval start.

Can we set the local cache size back to 0 and updates the docs?

I believe this can occur because of #509. #508 should help with this problem. The tricky part is that Druid does not distinguish between empty results because no segment is there versus empty results because a filter set did not match anything. In the first case, Druid should probably throw an exception and report a better status code.
Hi Yuval, we've done some work to optimize how post aggregations are calculated with recent code. Do you know if this is still an issue in the latest and if so, do you know the cause?
This has been fixed.
Yes, this is a mistake in the docs
OMG please! +1

This still appears to be an issue in today's master. I think the problem is around line 108 of GroupByQueryQueryToolChest.java. The IncrementalIndexStorageAdapter that's made out of the subquery results doesn't include postAggregations but should, so that the outer query can access them. I'm not sure how to fix it.
We should add this to docs too..

Not to mention the console work.

Hi Hagen, when you say rough idea of what is going on in a dimension, are you trying to find the cardinality of the dimension?
Thanks for fix!

No, this is a different use case: Assuming the value of the dimension is random, I still want to have "some" information about it in druid. Sample-agg essentially takes this dimension out of the pre-aggregation and leaves a single value for each row. I.e. it gives a sample.

I build it for a specific use case we can discuss in PM.

Thanks for the contrib! Before I can merge the pull request, we need you to
agree to our CLA. In the repo there is an individual CLA and a corporate
CLA. If you are working on your own behalf and agree to the CLA, responding
here with a comment of "I agree to the terms of the Druid Individual CLA as
it exists in the current master branch" is sufficient. If you are working on
behalf of a company, can you have your company fill out the corporate CLA
and submit it to us? Thanks again!

On Thu, May 22, 2014 at 3:42 AM, Deepak notifications@github.com wrote:

> For 12GB input data containing 8000 files, there are 8000 mappers because
> of TextInputFormat and its a overhead. The two MR jobs take around a day to
> complete.
> 
> CombineTextInputFormat instead of TextInputFormat combines multiple splits
> for a single mapper and reduces the strain on hadoop platform. It greatly
> improves job completion time as there are fewer number of mappers to
> bookkeep.
> 
> mapreduce.input.fileinputformat.split.maxsize controls amount of data
> given to a single mapper. Ex: setting it to 67,108,864 (64M) will create a
> 
> ## single mapper for 64M of data (hence multiple input files).

Hi sixtus, no documentation yet, but will try to get come out in the near future. We are still on the old schema, only problem is that we use hadoop index tasks and no longer use the standalone so this error got missed.

I needed this to work, so did a little investigating. It looks like there are two issues going on. First, in GroupByQueryQueryToolChest.mergeGroupByResult(), the call to makeIncrementalIndex when constructing the IncrementalIndexStorageAdapter is wrong. Instead of passing in the subquery, the query needs to be passed instead. This will include the necessary post-aggregator values correctly. The other problem is that mapping of fields between the inner and outer query is done using aggregators retrieved from AggregatorFactory.getCombiningFactory(), which due to its other uses, assumes that the name of the inner queries fields (aggregators or post-aggs) are the same as the outer query's aggregators that reference them. Effectively, "fieldName" in the outer queries aggregators will always be ignored and "name" used instead to find the underlying field.

I’m still waiting on our legal department to sign off on the CLA, so I’m unable to post a pull request at this time, but you can go ahead a send a fix.

When you are putting together the pull request, double check the unit tests. I found there was one other change I needed to make to suppress an exception that occurred when indexing data. It was having a problem around adding data when the inner query included a wider data range than the outer query. After looking at it, it appeared that this was actually a valid case, so I just commented out the exception.

Looking again, I think we do want to merge the subquery and apply the post-aggregations to the subquery before applying the outer query. In any case, I'll write up a test and try what you're suggesting.

It looked like the post-aggregations were working correctly against the subquery once I had made my change. When an aggregation in the outer query needed a post-aggregation, the value appeared to be correctly present.

Hey guys, sorry I'm late to the party. I took a look into this problem as well. I _think_ https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/593 will address the problem but more unit test will def help to make sure.

FJ can correct me, but I don't believe complex metrics currently work with any (even non-nested) groupBy queries. I believe it turns everything to a float. So, using doubleSum isn't making things worse. 

However, I'd also like to use complex metrics with groupBy queries. That seems to be a bigger change.

Uniques should work with group bys. I'm thinking about the case if we'd
ever have non finalized post aggregations...

> any (even non-nested) groupBy queries. I believe it turns everything to a

> seems to be a bigger change.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/593#issuecomment-45569495.

Don't assume that finalizing will return a float. I certainly have cases where my aggregator for a custom metric returns a non-float that I can further operate on in post aggregators. If my post aggregators happen to return the same custom metric that my aggegator expects as input, it would be perfectly reasonable to use them in nested queries.
Made several changes to remove the double sum aggregator and make sure all columns are included for all aggregator types

@fjy My use case is that I want to build a global jar including `druid-services`, `druid-rabbitmq`, postgresql JDBC drivers and few other things and all their dependencies.
This allows me easier sharing among the developers and easier deployments, eventually with custom patches or a next druid version snapshot.
To do that I have to declare druid as a submodule of my maven configuration and can't rely on dependencies download by maven because it will not be published in a maven repository.

I would like to take up this issue and have spoken to neo for a little background about it.

Assuming druid uses log4j for logging purposes a simple fix would be to use DailyRollingFileAppender instead of FileAppender. I found log4j.xml within druid/install module.  However after compilation i did not find it being bundled with tar, hence i manually copied the file and included it in classpath of historical node (used historical as example). It did not cause any affect.

In addition to using dailyrollingfileappender, i found this very useful appender called CustodianDailyRollingFileAppender by Ryan that does the following in addition to DailyRollingFileAppender
1) compress log files older than today
2) remove log files older than a specified number of days

through two additional settings
        <param name="MaxNumberOfDays" value="14"/>
        <param name="CompressBackups" value="true"/>

Will compress log files daily and delete them after 14 days.

I have made the above changes but unable to plug druid/install/log4j.xml into executable.

Hmm, we did some benchmarks with 10k select and they generally returned < 5s. Regardless, we have several features meant to improve the perf of this query that we will roll out soon (they've been merged into master already). FWIW, the query is still considered highly experimental :)

Why not build an indexing service task to change the schema?
A firehose is fine for small amounts of data, but if you need to change the schema on tens of thousands of segments this is not going to scale well, since it has to rebuild all the segments from scratch.
